content.raw:
The issue is that most installation problems are due to upstream changes (e.g. new versions of linux, OS X, Python, etc.), and usually not due to changes in Dedalus itself. This means that as time goes on, one specific version of the repo will become less likely than the tip to build correctly for the average person, because Jeff does a great job of responding to new stack issues as they arise and updating the install script to accomodate them.  This is why we generally want new installs to pull from the latest version of the main branch by default.

IIRC Jeff did put an option in the install script to specify the branch of the main repo that gets pulled, and I think you could replace that with any changeset hash you'd like if you want to setup an install script that will pull a certain version of the repo.

Another option is to consider using a prepackaged scientific python distribution (EPD, anaconda, etc.) to setup the basic stack, and then just doing the relatively straightforward Dedalus build on top of that.

content.raw:
Makes sense.  And you're correct, I just saw that Jeff does have a BRANCH environment variable that's default set to tip, and which can be manually set to any branch.

You're right -- it seems like a lot of the problems do come from problems outside of dedalus (once all of the dependencies are set up, I've never really had trouble installing it [unless something is wrong with a dependency]).  I assume that the reason that a lot of basic dependencies have been left up to package managers is partially (largely?) because a line like this:

```
#!bash

sudo apt-get install libatlas-base-dev libatlas3-base libopenmpi-dev openmpi-bin libssl-dev build-essential libncurses5 libncurses5-dev zip uuid-dev libfreetype6-dev tk-dev libhdf5-dev mercurial libzmq-dev libsqlite3-dev
```

is INFINITELY easier to call and debug than manually actually installing all of these like numpy, scipy, python, openmpi, etc.  And in most cases it works fine, so I don't really think it's a great idea to revamp that system.

So the way I'm seeing it is that there's not a great way to make sure that Dedalus releases are "stable" because the stability doesn't depend on Dedalus per se.  Would it be a good idea (or merely cumbersome) to somewhere track "OK, Dedalus installs fine on Ubuntu 15.04 version Y and Mac OS X.Z as of date/release ___"?

I don't necessarily think that this is something which should be constantly done.  However, for big changesets (like the one you did this summer where dedalus2 --> dedalus and all sorts of goodies were introduced) it might not be a bad idea to see which OS's and which versions of those OS's are up and running when those changes go out.

Feel free to shoot this down entirely or tweak any ideas.

content.raw:
The install script actually does manually build the python stack (python + numpy + scipy + matplotlib + h5py + mpi4py, mainly) -- the package manager call is to install the non-python dependencies of these packages, primarily things to make sure the python build succeeds.

You're definitely right that keeping track of what systems build out-of-the-box would be useful, it just takes time (and easy access to many systems) to setup and maintain that kind of thing.

content.raw:
One surprise too has been that, on Mac in particular, systems with nominally identical build environments (version of OSX, Xcode, etc.) can have markedly different success or failure using the install script.  I still don't understand the origin of that, and Macs have been particularly hard to test given our lack of access to Mac virtual machines.  

If anyone knows of where we can easily spin up a Mac virtual machine for testing the install script, please post here.

content.raw: We're now recommending conda be used instead of the install script, which will hopefully make installing the stack much easier.  Semi-regular date-based releases of Dedalus will also be pushed to PyPI to assist installation once the stack is properly setup.
